Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Deciphering Reductive Transformations of Heteroallenes at Bimetallic Platforms
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis program of the Chemistry Division, Stanislav Groysman of Wayne State University will investigate cooperative reductive transformations at bimetallic platforms. The research conducted in this project is motivated by the need to develop new efficient catalysts for carbon dioxide reduction. Reductive coupling of carbon dioxide provides a cost-efficient pathway leading to the higher-chain organic chemicals. Reductive splitting of carbon dioxide leads to the formation of fuels, carbon monoxide and methanol. The goal of the current project is to determine the factors controlling the nature of the reductive transformation of carbon dioxide, and to develop new catalysts for its reduction. The broader impacts of this program include the potential for the development of catalysts for the transformation of carbon dioxide into organic chemicals and fuels, as well as raising a new generation of scientists educated about the chemistry of small molecules crucial to the fields of energy and the environment.

The focus of the project is on the reductive coupling and reductive splitting of carbon dioxide and related heteroallenes. The goals are (1) to uncover key factors in the molecular chemistry of carbon dioxide determining the fate of its reductive transformation and (2) to develop new molecular catalysts for the reductive transformations of carbon dioxide. These goals will be achieved via structure-reactivity studies on bimetallic complexes featuring various geometric and electronic parameters (i. e. the distance between the metals and the nature of the ancillary ligands). The educational components of this program encompass the incorporation of a short course on the chemistry of small molecule activation into the existing curricula of undergraduate and graduate classes, conducting collaborative research with local undergraduate institutions, and developing interest in chemistry among high-school students in the area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis program of the Chemistry Division, Stanislav Groysman and his research group at Wayne State University designed and investigated new catalysts for the activation of CO2 and related substrates (CS2, alkynes). The particular focus of this study was on the reactivity of bimetallic systems, which are known to exhibit cooperative synergistic reactivity in small molecule activation and catalysis. This project deepened the understanding of the role of dinucleating ligands in catalysis. Specifically, this research provided insights into: (1) the role of redox-active ligands in small molecule activation, (2) the role of dinucleating ligand flexibility on the cooperative reactivity of the resulting dinuclear complexes. It was shown that redox-active iminopyridines serve as ?redox accumulators? stabilizing highly reduced metal centers by storing the reducing equivalents upon metal coordination. These reducing equivalents could then be transferred to the substrate of interest (CS2) upon its coordination to the metal, with the metal serving as a mediator. It was also demonstrated that very flexible open-chain dinucleating ligands (with p-xylylene bridges) do not exhibit cooperativity between the metals, while more rigid open-chain xanthene-bridged ligand positions metal closer and enables the desired cooperative reactivity. In contrast, the most rigid system, a macrocycle with two xanthene bridges, also did not exhibit cooperativity, due to its inability to achieve preferred conformation. Among the most notable practical outcomes of this award, new catalysts for H+ reduction, CO2 activation, alkyne cyclotrimerization, and cyclic ester polymerization were discovered and reported in the chemical literature.  

 

This project also achieved significant outcomes according to the ?Broader Impacts? criterion. Targeted broader impacts of this NSF awards included: (1) training of undergraduate and graduate students, (2) incorporation of pedagogical materials relevant to the proposed research into the courses that the PI was teaching; (3) participation of the PI and his lab in an outreach program with Detroit schools. (1) Five graduate students were trained as part of this award.  Following their graduation, they were able to obtain teaching/research positions. (2) The specific goal of the educational part of this award was ?development of a short course on activation of small molecules crucial to the fields of energy and the environment.? This objective was complementary to the proposed research, which targeted sustainable activation of CO2 and other heteroallenes using base metal catalysts. The PI created educational modules on: (i) the biogeochemical cycles of CO2, O2, and N2 and the roles they play in our environment, (ii) enzymatic chemistry of these molecules; (iii) synthetic/catalytic chemistry of these molecules. These modules were incorporated in the relevant classes that the PI taught. (3) The PI and his research group participated in the outreach program to the Detroit charter school University Preparatory Academy (UPrep). Most of the UPrep students are urban, underrepresented minorities, and the mission statement of the school states ?To prove that urban children can succeed in college through personalized learning and relentless commitment to their success.? PI?s research team conducted several lab tours for both middle-school and high-school UPrep students, which involved descriptions of the laboratory equipment including a hands-on experience in the inert-atmosphere gloveboxes, and chemistry demonstrations. The PI and his graduate students also participated in the career fair at UPrep, explaining to the students their career options in chemistry and how best to achieve them.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 07/01/2020
Modified by: Stanislav Groysman
